message: commit and push my changes except the readme file and the images

Here are the steps to commit and push your changes except the readme file and the images:
- Add all files except the readme file and the images to the staging area
- Commit the changes with a message
- Push the changes to the remote repository

```bash
git add -u :!README.md :!images
git commit -m "Commit message"
git push
```

The `git add -u` command adds all modified and deleted files to the staging area. The `:!README.md` and `:!images` options exclude the readme file and the images from being added. 

The `git commit` command creates a new commit with a message describing the changes made. 

Finally, the `git push` command pushes the changes to the remote repository.
commit and push my changes except the readme file and the images

Here are the steps to commit and push your changes except the readme file and the images:
- Add all files except the readme file and the images to the staging area
- Commit the changes with a message
- Push the changes to the remote repository

```bash
git add --all :!README.md :!images/*
git commit -m "Commit message"
git push
```

In the first command, we use the `git add` command with the `--all` option to add all files to the staging area. We also use the `:!<filename>` syntax to exclude the readme file and the images directory from being added.

In the second command, we use the `git commit` command with the `-m` option to add a commit message.

In the third command, we use the `git push` command to push the changes to the remote repository.

To undo the last local commit, you can use the following command:
```bash
git reset HEAD~1
```
This will remove the commit from your local branch, but keep the changes you made in your working directory. If you want to completely discard the changes as well, you can use the `--hard` option:
```bash
git reset --hard HEAD~1
```
Note that this will permanently delete the changes you made in the last commit, so use it with caution.
